resources.string:
"Received 20 points as a sign up gift.
- Things you can do with points 1. Lesson: Unlock Special Lessons 2. Reading: Unlock Readings 3. Writing: Ask a Korean teacher for correction
- How to collect points 1. Complete General Lessons 2. Watch video ads (in profile page) 3. Attend for 7 days in a row 4. Purchase"
Do you want to exit podo?
"Do you want to go back to main?\n(You can be rewarded points when you finish the lesson)"
"Do you want to go back to main?"
How to say numbers in Korean

"Many Korean learners think Korean numbers are really difficult. Because there are two systems of Korean numbers(Sino-Korean number / Native-Korean number) and you should use each number system depending on what the number is used for. Therefore whenever students say numbers, they are confused about which system of number to use.
In general, each number system is used in the following situations:
1.Sino-Korean number: Number itself 2.Native-Korean number: Counting numbers
But when you learn Korean numbers, you can see that this rule is not always correct. (For example, why the hour is Native-Korean number but the minute is Sino-Korean number?)
So I suggest to students 'Just listen and follow the correct number a lot. Then you will feel something strange right before you try to use the wrong number.'
This lesson is designed to learn Sino-Korean number and Native-Korean number as well as to practice the numbers repeatedly in different situations.
Let's practice until '일시 오분' and '십살' seem strange!"
Select a box to get the points

You can ask for a correction from a native Korean teacher by using 1 point per 1 letter. Feedback will be provided in 100% Korean. (Inappropriate writing such as abusive language may be rejected)
Are you sure you want to delete this collection?

"All Korean verbs and adjectives have a base form. It means things that end with '~다', such as '먹다 (to eat)', '가다 (to go)' and '사다 (to buy)'.
You'll use base forms when looking for a word on dictionary, but you should change the base form to the form that you want to use when talking or writing. For example, '먹다 (to eat)' changes as followed.
- 먹다 (to eat) : base form - 먹어요 (I eat) - 먹으면 (if I eat) - 먹어서 (because I eat) - 먹고 (after I eat)
For most of the words base forms you only need to change ""다"" to other forms. But sometimes there are irregular words that change parts that are not '다' as well. For example...
- 듣다 (to listen) : base form - 들어요 (I listen) - 들으면 (If I listen) - 들어서(because I listen) - 듣고(after I listen)
Many students think that irregular words are difficult, but you don't need to worry about that. Because most of irregular forms are for easier pronunciation. In the example above, you can pronounce easier by changing irregularly to '들어요[드러요]' instead of '듣어요[드더요]'. Therefore, if you use it several times through speaking practice, you will naturally be able to remember irregular words."

"The first conjugation you learn is the '아요/어요' form. Let's call it '아/어요' for short. '아/어요' is not too formal and can be polite enough. Therefore, it is most often used in everyday conversations.
There are three rules for converting the base form to '아/어요'. Let's take a look with an example.(You don't need to know the meaning of the words in the example right now. Let's focus on the process of changing the base form into '아/어요'.)
1.
하다 -> 해요 : The base form of a verb or adjective ending with '~하다' is simply converted to '해요'.
ex) 공부하다 -> 공부해요 운동하다 -> 운동해요 좋아하다 -> 좋아해요
2.
When there is a vowel 'ㅏ' or 'ㅗ' -> 아요 : In the base form, you should see the letter right before the '다'. If the letter has a vowel 'ㅏ' or 'ㅗ', this word should be added with '아요'. Let's take a look the word '가다'. The previous letter of '다' is '가' and '가' has a vowel 'ㅏ'. Therefore, the word '가다' is conjugated to '가' + '아요' = '가아요', and '가아요' can be simplified to '가요'.
ex) '오다' -> '오' + '아요' = '오아요' -> '와요' '만나다' -> '만나' + '아요' = '만나아요' -> '만나요' '살다' -> '살' + '아요' -> '살아요'
3.
Everything except 1 and 2 -> 어요 : Let's look at the word '먹다. This word doesn't end with '하다'. And since the vowels of the '먹' is 'ㅓ', it's not type 2 as well. Therefore, this word is type 3 and you should add '어요'.
ex) '먹다' -> '먹' + '어요' = '먹어요' '배우다' -> '배우' + '어요' = '배우어요' -> '배워요' '읽다' -> '읽' + '어요' = '읽어요'
So far, we have looked at the '아/어요' and let's make a promise with me now. Just think about this rule until Lesson 10 and forget about this. Actually there are only a few Koreans who know this rule. When you learn new verbs or adjectives just take a look '아/어요' as well. And just say '아요' or '어요' as it is pronounced comfortably. It might be correct.
I'm going to say one more interesting thing and finish this lesson. The '아/어요' is so powerful that it can have a variety meanings depending on how you speak or what's the situation.
For example, let's see the word '먹어요'. a. '먹어요.' (You eat) b. '먹어요?' (Do you eat?) c. '먹어요!!' (You must to eat!) There are many other meanings, but let's just remember two things of 'a' and 'b'."

"Students who use a language without particles have a lot of difficulty with particles in Korean. The most difficult are '은/는', '이/가' and '을/를'. We'll learn each particle later and I'm going to explain why we use the particles in this lesson.
There are two sentences in English.
1. I eat lion. 2. Lion eat I. (Of course,'The lion eats me' is correct but ignore it now)
The subject of sentence 1 is 'I' and the object is 'lion'. However, the subject of sentence 2 is 'lion' and the object is 'I'. In other words, depending on the position of the word, the subject and the object are determined and the meaning of sentence becomes completely different.
Now let's look at the Korean sentence using particles.
1. 나는 사자를 먹어요 2. 사자를 나는 먹어요
'나' meaning 'I' is added subject particle '는' and '사자' meaning 'lion' is added object particle '를'. When you use particles, the role of the word is fixed. So the sentence always has the same meaning no matter where the word is. Therefore, sentence 1 and 2 is totally same meaning as 'I eat lion'.
This is the difference between a language that uses particles and a language that does not. But it's not a good idea to change the position of words all the time. Korean language generally uses the order of 'subject-object-predicate', so it would be better to follow this order."

"There are 2 basic tips to make your pronunciation better.
1.
The consonant (not batchim) 'ㅇ' is a kind of an empty place because it has no sound. Therefore, when there is a batchim before the consonant 'ㅇ', you can put this batchim into the place of the consonant 'ㅇ' for reading naturally. For example, '사람이에요' has a batchim 'ㅁ' in the letter '람' and the next letter of '이' has a consonant 'ㅇ' that is an empty place. So it is good to read [사라미에요].
2.
batchim 'ㅎ' makes following consonants stronger. If the consonants 'ㄱ', 'ㄷ', 'ㅈ' comes after batchim 'ㅎ', they sound each 'ㅋ', 'ㅌ', 'ㅊ'.
ex) - '좋다' -> [조타] - '놓고' -> [노코] - '많지' -> [만치] "

"1. 5시에 운동을 해요. 2. 5시에서 운동을 해요.
Which one is correct?
1.
Use '에' after the noun to indicate the time.
ex) - 5시에 운동을 해요. - 아침에 학교를 가요. - 저녁에 약속이 있어요.
2.
Use '에서' after the noun to indicate the place.
ex) - 학교에서 한국어를 공부해요. - 집에서 TV를 봐요. - 식당에서 밥을 먹어요.
Isn't it too easy? Now, let's learn a little bit more.
2-1.
In a sentence with a verb indicating existence (있다/없다) and a verb indicating movement (가다/오다/도착하다/다니다...), we use '에' after the noun indicating the place.
ex) - 서점에 책이 있어요. - 밖에 사람이 없어요. - 병원에 가요. - 어제 한국에 도착했어요. - 한국어 학교에 다녀요.
In other words, we unconditionally use '에' after the noun that indicating the time, and we basically use ""에서"" after the noun that indicates the place. but sometimes use '에' after the noun that indicating the place according to verb of its sentence. "

"How do you say the words below in Korean?
- Bibimbap restaurant - Spaghetti restaurant - tteokbokki restaurant
- 비빔밥 식당 - 스파게티 식당 - 떡볶이 식당
Is that right?
You can say '식당' when you talk about a restaurant. But native speakers often say the 'food' + '집'(house). So the restaurants above could be
- 비빔밥집 - 스파게티집 - 떡볶이집
In this way, it can be much more natural. Well, how can we say Korean restaurant? Korean food is called '한국 음식' and is called '한식' shortly. Therefore, you can say '한식집' or '한식당'. "

"1.
As we learned in previous lesson, '아서/어서' is used as a reason or cause.
ex) - 만나서 반가워요. ('만나다' -> '만나서') - 저거는 50% 세일이어서 5,000원이에요. ('이다' -> '이어서') - 겨울이어서 날씨가 추워요. ('이다' -> '이어서')
'이다 -> 이어서' is better to say '이라서' in the conversation. So in the real conversation the above are ...
- 저거는 50% 세일이라서 5,000원이에요. - 겨울이라서 날씨가 추워요.
2.
We also use '아서/어서' to refer to the relationship between time. At this time, there must be a close connection between what happened before and what happened afterwards.
ex) - 한국에 가서 한국어를 배워요. - 친구를 만나서 얘기해요. - 식당에 가서 밥을 먹어요. "

"'Newly-coined word' is a new word made popular by young people. Some people say it's better not to use it because it's not a standard language. But I think it is helpful to foreigners to make learning korean more fun. However, it is recommended not to use it in formal situations.
Well, let's look at some of the most common new words used in 2019.
1. 인플루언서
: Korean pronunciation of English 'influencer'. It means the people who have a large number of followers In social media and influence the public.
2. 편스토랑
: A combination of '편의점 (convenience store)' and '레스토랑 (restaurant)'. It means a convenience store where you can have a good meal like a restaurant.
3. 소떡소떡
: It's a snack that '소시지 (sausage)' and '떡 (rice cake)' are alternately sticked and baked. That's why it is called '소떡소떡'.
4. 스포
: It's from English 'spoiler'. The act of telling others about the contents of a movie in advance.
5. 꾸안꾸
: It is made up of shortened '꾸민 듯 안 꾸민 듯 (like not put makeup)'. It means that you put on makeup naturally, as if you did not do makeup."

"Since Korea used Chinese characters in the past, there are lots of words made from Chinese characters.
Usually formal writing uses the words from Chinese character. Therefore, if you don't know the words from Chinese character, you could be overwhelmed because there are too many unknown words when you start reading Korean articles.
However, because each Chinese character has its own meaning, learning very easy Chinese characters can help you to understand the meaning of words. Therefore, let's pick only very easy Chinese characters and learn together.
The first Chinese character we will learn is '人'(사람 인). This Chinese character has the meaning of '사람'(people) and the sound of '인'. The shape of this letter is also very interesting. It is a letter made of people walking as shown in the picture above. Therefore, if there is a letter '인' in Korean word, we can guess that it is related to 'people'.
ex) - 한국인 : Korean - 인간 : human - 인구 : population - 인격 : personality "

"1. 저는 스키를 좋아요. 2. 저는 스키를 좋아해요.
Which one is correct?
1.
Use '좋아요' after the Subject(which is able to use with '이/가') and it's base form is '좋다'(good). So it means the 'Subject' is good.
ex) - 저는 스키가 좋아요. - 저는 치킨이 좋아요. - 오늘은 날씨가 좋아요.
2.
Use '좋아해요' after the Object(which is able to use with '을/를') and it's base form is '좋아하다'(like). So it means the 'Subject' likes 'Object'.
ex) - 저는 스키를 좋아해요. - 저는 치킨을 좋아해요. - 눈이 오는 날씨를 좋아해요.
Sometimes we omit '은/는' and '이/가' in real conversation. In this case, never be confused, you just remember it means 'good' or 'like'."

" 1.
1) 시간이 없어서 빨리 가세요. 2) 시간이 없으니까 빨리 가세요.
Which one is correct?
'아/어서' is not allowed in 'order' or 'request' statements. Therefore, sentence 1) is a weird sentence. Likewise, instead of '이 식당은 비빔밥이 맛있어서 비빔밥 먹으세요', '이 식당은 비빔밥이 맛있으니까 비빔밥 먹으세요' is the correct expression.
2.
1) 한국에 살았어서 한국어를 잘해요. 2) 한국에 살았으니까 한국어를 잘해요.
Which one is correct?
'으니까' is not available for past tense. Therefore, sentence 1) is correct.
3.
1) 만나서 반가워요. 2) 만났으니까 반가워요.
Which one is correct?
Everyone can easily see that 1) is the right sentence. But you may not know why. '으니까' cannot be used in adjectives expressing emotions. For example, '반갑다', '고맙다', '미안하다'.
SUMMARY) There are three rules, but you don't have to remember them all. Usually, you can use '아/어서' and use '으니까' only when expressing 'order' or 'request'. "

"No matter in the morning, afternoon, evening, we say hello like this. You can just say '안녕' to your close friend (friend means same age) or a close sister/brother (It means a close friend that is younger than you)"
We say this to someone who met for the first time or after a long time.
Conventionally asking if nothing has happened so far.

"가세요' is from 'to go' and '계세요' is from 'to stay'. Therefore, if the other person will 'go' from here after saying goodbye, we say '안녕히 가세요' and if the other person will 'stay' here after saying goodbye, we say '안녕히 계세요'. If they are close friends or younger friends, you can just say goodbye like this '안녕'."

"This expression is very useful when you have questions. You can point your finger at something you don't know and say ‘이거 뭐예요?’ (what's this?) When you point something out a little farther away, you can say '저거 뭐예요?' (what's that?)"

"You may be wondering what '이' is after '이름'. This is the main challenge for Korean language learners, called 'subject particle' but don't struggle to know it now. Just remember that you can also say '이름 뭐예요?' but '이름이 뭐예요?' is a better expression. It is important to get used to it in this level. (See the special lesson ‘particles 1 : Why we use particles?)"

"If there isn't a batchim (last consonant) in the previous letter, we use ‘예요’.
If there is a batchim in the previous letter, we use ‘이에요’."
"사람이에요 [사라미에요] (See the special lesson 'Speaking Naturally 1 : Pronunciation rule')"
Find out what your country is in Korean and make it into a sentence.
"‘이거’ is used a lot in the conversational language. And you should say ‘이것‘ in the formal situation."
"‘저거’ is used a lot in the conversational language. And you should say ‘저것‘ in the formal situation."
"You can say like this for short of '저거는 얼마예요?'"
Do you have a Korean friend?
Yes, I have a korean friend.
"You can say this when you 'have' something or someone 'exists'. In Korean, we don't consider singular and plural that much and the meaning of 'There isn't' is '없다'."

"When you conjugate verbs or adjectives to the form of '아요/어요', if you say it with a lower intonation, it's a statement. But if you raise the intonation at the end, it becomes a question.
ex) '있어요?' : is there? '있어요.' : there is."
"There are lots of unit nouns in Korean. Don't try to learn all at once. Just remember to use '명' for people and '개' for things."
The words that describe the place should be followed by the place particle \'에서\'.
kakao talk: Messenger name used by most Koreans
"Because KakaoTalk is used as a place, '에서' is added."
"When you say past tense, you only need to put 'ㅆ어' into the form of '아요/어요'. Therefore, we can call the past tense to '았어요/었어요' form. '있어요' -> '있어(ㅆ어)요' = '있었어요'"
I will go to the restaurant.
I will go to a Korean restaurant.
I will go to a Korean restaurant with my friend.
I will watch an interesting movie.

"When we say future tense, we conjugate 'ㄹ 거예요/을 거예요' form. If there is no batchim, add 'ㄹ 거예요'. If there is a batchim, add '을 거예요'.
conjugate 'ㄹ 거예요/을 거예요' : '하다' -> '하' + 'ㄹ 거예요' = '할 거예요'"
"If you use verbs related to movement ('가다', '오다', '들어가다' etc ...) we add '에' after the noun that is the destination. We can also omit '에' in the conversation. (See the special lesson '에 vs. 에서')"
"We can say ‘랑/이랑’ for the conversational language."
"Object particle is used. However, we can omit object particles when speaking. '영화를 볼 거예요' -> '영화 볼 거예요'"
Let\'s go to the gym together
Let\'s go the gym together later
"conjugate '고 있다' : '가다' -> '가' + '고 있다' = '가고 있다' conjugate '아요/어요' : '가고 있다' -> '가고 있' + '어요' = '가고 있어요'"
"If you use verbs related to movement ('가다', '오다', '들어가다' etc ...) we add '에' after the noun that is the destination. We can also omit ""에"" when speaking (See the special lesson '에 vs. 에서')"
"You can also use '랑/이랑' that we learned in the previous lesson. '저' (a polite expression of 'me') + '랑' = '저랑 헬스장에 가요' Or you can also use '랑/이랑' with '같이' means together. '저랑 같이 헬스장에 가요'"
"When you want to express a short time within a few hours, use '이따' or '이따가'. It's for conversational speaking."

"conjugate '아요/어요' : '춥다' -> '춥' + '어요' = '춥어요' -> '추워요' (exception)
Most exceptions are for ease of pronunciation. '추워요' is more comfortable and natural to pronounce than '춥어요'."

"You can make negative forms by using '안' before a verb or adjective. When a verb composed of 'noun + 하다' is made into a negative sentence, it should be written as 'noun + 안 + 하다'.
ex) '얘기하다' -> '얘기 안 하다'
Negative sentences using '안' are direct expressions. If you want to express it indirectly, use '~지 않다'.
ex) '얘기하다' -> '얘기하지 않다'"
I\'m so tired because I\'m very busy recently.
I can\'t wake up early in the morning.
So I can\'t have breakfast as well
I can\'t have breakfast as well because I can\'t wake up early in the morning.
"Use '아서/어서' to combine two sentences together using '그래서'. conjugate '아요/어요' : '바쁘다' -> '바쁘' + '아요' = '바쁘아요' -> '바빠요' conjugate '아서/어서' : '바빠요' -> '바빠' + '아서' = '바빠아서' -> '바빠서'"

"안' : do not '못' : can not
'못 일어나요 ' -> [몬 이러나요]"
"We can use '도' to mean 'also'. '아침/점심/저녁' means 'morning / noon / night' respectively. Also, they have the meaning of 'breakfast / lunch / dinner.'"
How do you get to the company.
How do you get to the company from home.
"When referring to a range of places, use '~에서 ~까지'."
How many hours do you work?
I work from 9 am to 6 pm.
"When referring to a range of time, use '~부터 ~까지'. It\'s also okay to use '~에서 ~ 까지' like a range of places"
Yes, I like BTS the most.
BTS is good at singing and dancing as well.
BTS is good at singing and dancing as well.

"Use '~고' to combine two sentences together using '그리고'.
ex) '부르다' -> '부르' + '고' = '부르고'"
Speaking and writing are difficult but reading is easy.
Speaking and writing are difficult but reading is easy.

"Use '~지만' to combine two sentences together using '하지만'.
ex) '어렵다' -> '어렵' + '지만' = '어렵지만'"

"When you change a verb to a noun, you can use '~기' like '~ing' in English.
ex) '말하다' -> '말하기' (speak -> speaking) '쓰다' -> '쓰기' (write -> writing) '읽다'-> '읽기' (read -> reading)"
Take this medicine before you have a meal
Take this medicine 30 minutes before you have a meal
"감기' and '걸리다' is a commonly used word, so it is good to memorize it together."

"You can also use 'N + 전에' instead of 'V + 기 전에' However, only nouns that can be used as 'N + 하다' (nouns that represent actions) are possible.
ex) '식사' + '하다' = '식사하다' (o) 식사 하기 전에~ 식사 전에~ '쇼핑' + '하다' = '쇼핑하다' (o) 쇼핑 하기 전에~ 쇼핑 전에 ~"
What do you do at night?
What will you do at night today?
I\'ll have dinner after finishing work.
I\'ll have dinner after finishing work with my family.
I watch a drama after having dinner.
I\'ll watch a drama after having dinner.
Did you watch any dramas recently?
"You can also say '뭐 할거예요?' when using future tense like you learned in previous lesson. But in situations where the content of the future is clear, such as 'tonight', you can use the present tense."

"If the verb doesn't have a batchim, use 'V-ㄴ 후에' and use 'V-은 후에' when it has a batchim. '끝나다' -> '끝나' + 'ㄴ 후에' = '끝난 후에' You can also use 'N + 후에' instead. Of course, nouns that can only be uses as 'N + 하다' (nouns that represent actions) are possible like 'N + 전에'.
ex) '운동' + '하다' = '운동하다' (o) 운동 한 후에~ 운동 후에~"
"When you ask something, you can use '~아/어 주세요'. '추천하다' -> 추천해요' -> '추천해' + '주세요' = '추천해 주세요'"
I can understand a little bit.

"Use it when you have the ability to do something. On the contrary, when you don't have an ability to do something, you can say 'V-(으)ㄹ 수 없다'. You can also use '못' learned from 'negative2'.
conjugate 'V-(으)ㄹ 수 있다/없다' : '이해하다' -> '이해하' + 'ㄹ 수 있다' = '이해할 수 있다' : '이해하다' ->' 이해하' + 'ㄹ 수 없다' = '이해할 수 없다'
negative '못' : '이해하다' -> '이해 못 하다'"
It can be used when it\'s not very good but not that bad.
"The unit noun representing the number of times is '번'."
There\'s a lot of similar words.
There\'s a lot of similar words with Japanese.
There\'s a lot of similar words with Japanese in Korean.
Therefore, it could be easier than other languages.
We\'ve learned in the last lesson that this means "ability"
"(See the special lesson 'Confusing expression2 - 좋아요 vs. 좋아해요')"
"We can use 'A-(으)ㄴ' form when the adjective modifies a noun. '비슷하다' -> '비슷하' + 'ㄴ' = '비슷한'"

"We've learned that we can use 'V-(으)ㄹ 수 있다' form when it means an ability to do something in the previous lesson. But one more meaning can be used, which is the 'possibility'. When it means possibility, you can use adjectives as well as verbs.
conjugate 'A/V-(으)ㄹ 수 있다' '쉽다' -> '쉽' + '을 수 있다' = '쉽을 수 있다' -> '쉬울 수 있다' (irregular)"
I want to travel to Korea.
I want to travel to Korea on this vacation.
What do you want to do?
What do you want to do in Korea?
I want to eat Korean food.
I want to eat Korean food a lot.
I want to practice Korean too.
And I want to practice Korean too.
You will be able to do it well.
You will be able to do it well because you studied Korean very hard.
Cool! You will be able to do it well because you learned Korean very well.

"Use the 'V-고 싶다' form to tell the wishes or hopes of the speaker.
conjugate 'V-고 싶다' '가다' -> '가' + '고 싶다' = '가고 싶다'"
"이번 : this time 저번 : last time 다음 : next time"
"A 'V-(으)ㄹ 수 있다' form was used to represent the 'ability' that we learned in the previous lesson."
"Used future tense to express the speaker's expectations."

"Use the 'A/V-(으)니까' form to tell the 'reason'. You can also use the 'A/V-아/어서' form that you learned in the 'negative2' lesson.
'공부 열심히 했으니까' = '공부 열심히 해서' (See the special lesson 'Confusing expression3 - ~아/어서 vs. ~으니까')"
Please help me book a hotel
Is it your first time to go to Busan?
"Use '저' instead of '나' when you speak honorific."
"이번 주 : this week 저번 주: last week 다음 주: next week"

"Use the 'V-아/어 주세요' form to ask something.
conjugate 'V-아/어 주세요' '돕다' -> '돕아요' -> '도와요' (irregular) '도와요' -> '도와' + '주세요' = '도와주세요'"
"Using '좀' means 'a little' when asking for help in more polite expressions."

"In English, there are many forms like 'reservation', 'booking' and 'appointment' but they are all '예약' in Korean.
ex) 호텔예약 : booking 식당예약 : reservation 병원예약 : appointment"
